title-group.article-title: With God on my side: The paradoxical relationship between religious belief and criminality among hardcore street offenders

author-notes.corresp: Volkan Topalli, Department of Criminal Justice & Criminology, The Andrew Young School of Policy Studies, Georgia State University, PO Box 4018, Atlanta, GA 30302-4018, USA. Email: vtopalli@gsu.edu

abstract.p: Research has found that many street offenders anticipate an early death, making them less prone to delay gratification, more likely to discount the future costs of crime, and thus more likely to offend. Ironically, many such offenders also hold strong religious convictions, including those related to the punitive afterlife consequences of offending. To reconcile these findings, we interviewed 48 active street offenders to determine their expectation of an early demise, belief in the afterlife, and notions of redemption and punishment. Despite the deterrent effects of religion that have been highlighted in prior research, our results indicate that religion may have a counterintuitive criminogenic effect in certain contexts. Through purposeful distortion or genuine ignorance, the hardcore offenders we interviewed are able to exploit the absolvitory tenets of religious doctrine, neutralizing their fear of death to not only allow but encourage offending. This suggests a number of intriguing consequences for deterrence theory and policy.

disp-quote.p: If death were a release from everything, it would be a boon for the wicked.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: The role of religion in regulating and guiding behavior in mainstream society is well documented (McCullough and Willoughby, 2009). Religion has been found to play a role in everything from consumer consumption and personal finances (Coşgel and Minkler, 2004; Hess, 2012), to health decisions (Idler, 1995), to paying taxes (Bräutigam et al., 2008; Fjeldstad and Semboja, 2001; Ongwamuhana, 2011) to jury decisions in capital cases (Miller, 2006) (for a review of contemporary effects of religion on society see Herbert, 2003; for a historical view of religion’s impact on western society see Mathisen, 2006). In criminology and sociology, religion is seen to reduce participation in crime through a variety of mechanisms (see Akers et al., 2008; Cochran and Akers, 1989). Both social bonding theory (Hirschi, 1969) and social learning theory (Burgess and Akers, 1966) have been applied as explanations for this phenomenon.

According to social bonding theorists, religion is seen to constrain or control offending by strengthening the connections between would-be criminals and society through acceptance of mainstream values (Akers, 2010). Such bonds are established by emphasizing religious beliefs, commitment, activities, and behaviors that are incongruent with law breaking (Hirschi, 1969; Hirschi and Gottfredson, 1995; Schreck, 2009). Relatedly, social learning theory contends that religion provides the would-be offender with ‘definitions unfavorable’ to crime, vicariously reinforced through exposure to law-abiding role-models, and encouraging participation in non-criminal mainstream activities. Psychologists (see Carver and Scheier, 1999; McCullough and Willoughby, 2009) see religion as a self-regulatory mechanism that enhances self-control and influences how goals are adopted, pursued, and organized. Self-regulation serves to select out criminal behavior and promote prosocial behavior.

Such effects are assumed to accrue because religious doctrine underpins much of mainstream society’s values, rules, and laws (see Berman, 1974; Fowler, 1985; Gedicks and Hendrix, 1987). But religions (particularly those in the Judeo-Christian tradition) are themselves specified social systems designed to independently guide individual human behavior. As such, they also clearly define consequences of bad behavior that go beyond those imposable by formal social control agents (governments) through the criminal justice system, or by informal social control agents (aggrieved individuals) through retaliation or vigilantism (see Bentham, 1781/1907). Specifically, in western society the notion of punishment in the afterlife is assumed to be a powerful deterrent of deviance and is the bedrock of how many religions seek to control human behavior (see Kosmin and Lachman, 1994; Raven, 1999; Weber, 1922).1

There is evidence in the non-criminological literature that when death or danger are salient, individuals are more likely to consider the afterlife implications of their current behavior (see, for example, Ochsmann, 1984; Osarchuk and Tatz, 1973; Rose and O’Sullivan, 2002). Street offenders in particular lead dangerous lives, making the existential costs of their behaviors and life choices (i.e. death or serious injury) salient, which should also make salient the related transcendental costs of such behavior (i.e. punishment in the afterlife). To the extent that would-be offenders fear the transcendental consequences of their behavior, crime and deviance should be reduced.

For several reasons, we propose that the religious beliefs of such offenders warrant further scientific scrutiny. First, studies in this area typically employ general samples and test for a negative, inhibiting effect of religion on criminal conduct. This approach, however, assumes that religion has the same inhibiting effect across all members of the population. Yet if this assumption is faulty, then such studies may actually underestimate the effects of religion. For instance, if religion exerts countervailing effects—inhibiting crime for most individuals, but facilitating crime for certain subgroups—then the observed effect of religion would be diminished in the typical study, or perhaps, difficult to detect. In fact, the effects of religious beliefs and behaviors have been inconsistent across studies, though most observe a modest inhibiting effect of religion, especially on victimless offenses such as drug and alcohol use (for a meta-analysis of relevant studies, see Baier and Wright, 2001). By examining the religious beliefs of serious offenders in the context of an in-depth qualitative study, we take an initial step beyond the usual approach and explore whether or not religion/religiosity functions differently within this particular subgroup.

Second, an examination of this type may shed additional light on offenders’ decision-making processes and should be of special interest to neutralization theorists. Third, the findings may have implications for policy. As we discuss in the conclusion section of the article, it appears that serious street offenders process and apply religious doctrine in unique and surprising ways. Faith-based programs, in particular, may benefit from this knowledge.

To explore these issues and possibilities, the current study utilizes qualitative interviews from 48 offenders who regularly engage in serious crime and violence. These drug dealers, street robbers, and carjackers were all currently active in offending at the time of their interviews. (That is to say, they were all non-institutionalized and operating on some of the most dangerous streets in the city of Atlanta.)

sec.title: The role of religious belief among serious street offenders
Dealing with fear
sec.p: Street offenders lead exceedingly dangerous lives, operating outside the bounds of the law and relying only on their wits and will to navigate a world where the threat of retaliation, crimes gone wrong, or police action places them at risk for the daily possibility of injury, paralysis, and death (see Dobrin, 2001; Hoffman, 2000; Jacobs et al., 2000; McCarthy and Hagan, 2005; Sampson and Lauritsen, 1994; Topalli et al., 2002; Tremblay and Paré, 2003). The criminological record is replete with accounts by offenders that describe numerous life-and-death encounters and occurrences. Many experienced offenders—even those who are by most standards quite young—have endured stabbings, shootings, or other horrific life-threatening injuries and yet remain committed to a risky and criminal lifestyle (Anderson, 1994, 1999; Hoffman, 2000; Jacobs et al., 2000; McCarthy and Hagan, 2005; Topalli, 2005a).

How and why are street criminals so fearless and undaunted? Why are they not deterred by the prospect of either formal or informal lethal sanctions (i.e. the death penalty or the possibility of being shot dead in the streets)? Previous research suggests that many offenders experience a heightened sense of ‘futurelessness’ and fatalism as a consequence of growing up and living in economically distressed, high-crime communities where a lack of opportunities and the prospect of a violent death are ever present (Anderson, 1994, 1999; Garbarino et al., 1992; Kitwana, 2002; Simons and Burt, 2011; Wilson and Daly, 1997). Brezina et al. (2009) found that such attitudes underpin a perceptual orientation of many offenders that their deaths are imminent, unpredictable, and nearly unavoidable. They argued that individuals with no future prospects have little to lose by engaging in crime and violence, and focus instead on the immediate reward and gratification provided by their offending in the moment (see Katz, 1988; Wright and Topalli, 2011). It is important to note however, they did not contend that offenders completely ignore the future or that they do not fear death. As Hochstetler and Copes (2003: 89) note, ‘fear factors into the decision-making process of many offenders. Few offenders give their crimes and the potential consequences careful consideration, but this is not evidence that dreadful thoughts do not cross their minds at some time’.

Indeed, if criminals were wholly oblivious or disdainful of the legal or existential consequences of their actions they would consistently act with impulsive, reckless abandon, precluding any sort of planful behavior. This is clearly not the case, as offenders frequently report planning their offenses and thinking about the extralegal consequences of their actions (see Fleming, 2003; Tunnell, 1992; Wright and Decker, 1997).2 In fact, most hardcore offenders do fear death and contemplate the consequences of their actions, but it seems that such considerations are far less salient for them than for members of mainstream society, and certainly not salient enough to act as a comprehensive deterrent (Hochstetler and Copes, 2003), particularly when they are desperate or close to the moment of the offense itself (Wright and Topalli, 2011). What appears evident is that in the same way offenders must neutralize the guilt they may anticipate for committing crime (Sykes and Matza, 1957), so too must they neutralize the fear they anticipate of both the proximate and distal consequences of committing crime.

Doing so may require offenders to employ a variety of behavioral strategies, such as consuming judgment-dulling alcohol and drugs before committing a crime, or relying on the encouragement of co-offenders to steel themselves for the contemplated law breaking ahead. They may also employ a variety of self-enhancing cognitive ‘tricks’ or techniques such as redefining crime as thrilling (Fleming, 2003; Peersen et al., 2004; Webe, 2004) or mundane (Sutherland, 1937; Topalli, 2006). Such self-enhancing and self-deceptive thought processes are well documented by researchers in the social cognition literature (see, for example, Taylor et al., 2000), and are particularly helpful for those seeking to mitigate the anxiety associated with the consideration of death and mortality (Greenberg et al., 1986, 2001). But, are legal and existential consequences the only ones they may actually contemplate? To what extent do they consider the transcendental consequences (i.e. punishment in the afterlife) that may also—at least in their minds—result from criminality? In other words, what role do religious beliefs play in either deterring or encouraging criminality among serious street offenders?

sec.title: Religiosity, deterrence, and criminality
sec.p: Both deterrence theory and situational crime prevention focus on the extent to which instilling fear in criminals of the consequences of offending serves as a means of dissuading them from breaking the law (Clarke, 1992). Since most research on deterrence theory is designed to inform crime policy, work in this area has largely been limited to the impact of formal legal sanctions (i.e. imprisonment) on criminality. However, research has also shown that informal mainstream consequences such as shame, loss of employment or status, isolation, and so on, also affect many would-be offenders and such deterrents have been found at times to be even more powerful than fear of legal sanctions (see, for example, Erickson et al., 1977; Grasmick and Green, 1980; Tittle, 1980).

Beyond that, transgressions within the criminal underworld can also trigger ‘street’ sanctions that are uniquely salient to offenders such as the situational deterrent measures that offender/victims can employ (i.e. retaliation; see Jacobs, 2010; Jacobs et al., 2000) or the threatened loss of reputation and respect (see Anderson, 1994; Berg and Stewart, 2009; Topalli et al., 2002). A much less well-studied category of sanction has to do with the interrelated existential and transcendental consequences of criminality, namely the fear of crime-precipitated death and subsequent anticipated punishment in the afterlife.

Such assumptions are implicit in previous work by criminologists on the power of religion to deter offending. Much of that literature focuses on the ability of religion to constrain or control offending by strengthening the bonds between would-be criminals and society, with the assumption that such bonds increase a person’s loyalty to and acceptance of mainstream values (Akers, 2010). In keeping with a classical social bonding approach (Hirschi, 1969; Schreck, 2009), religion is assumed to encourage prosocial behavior by emphasizing religious beliefs, commitment, and activities. Although early research seemed to disprove such an effect (see, for example, Hirschi and Stark’s classic 1969 article on the ‘hellfire’ effect) it has partially been supported by subsequent work demonstrating that religious behaviors (e.g. church attendance, prayer) and beliefs (e.g. belief in God, in the Bible) can serve to deter risky behaviors in general (Wallace et al., 2007) and offending in particular (see Akers, 2010; Akers et al., 2008; Cochran and Akers, 1989; Evans et al., 1995; Stark, 1996; for a meta-analysis, see Baier and Wright, 2001).

However, most researchers in this area tend to focus on the role of mainstream-oriented religiosity, where it is expected that the religious beliefs of the individual are ‘conventional’ and shared by others members of the community. In fact, evidence indicates that religion exhibits stronger deterrent effects on crime in communities where overall levels of religiosity are high (Baier and Wright, 2001; Stark, 1996). In such communities, individuals are likely to be surrounded by liked-minded believers, who help to enforce the mainstream value system. But what happens when religious belief becomes disconnected from the mainstream value system?

As Akers (2010) points out, there are times when religion is purposely manipulated to serve ends that are decidedly counter to mainstream values, as when religious indoctrination is oriented toward encouraging terrorism (see Atran, 2003; Berko and Erez, 2005, 2006; Hamm, 2009; Kruglanski et al., 2009). In such cases, a ‘warped’ anti-mainstream religious message is communicated externally (by proponents of terroristic action) to individuals to encourage them to violence in the name of either religious obligation or potential transcendental rewards (i.e. heaven, ‘72 virgins’ etc., see Routledge and Arndt, 2008).

Another heretofore-unconsidered possibility is that offenders themselves may employ (either purposefully or out of ignorance) alternatively distorted and/or self-serving religious narratives to justify their offending behavior and neutralize any deterrent effect that fear of transcendental negative outcomes would normally have. To the extent that such manipulations are successful, religiosity may fail to deter crime in such cases and may, in fact, facilitate persistent criminality.

sec.title: Methodological justification
sec.p: Most serious street crimes are committed by a small, dedicated group of individuals in concentrated areas of most cities (see Braga, 2003, 2005; Kennedy, 1997; Sherman, 2001, 2006; Weisburd et al., 2009). Our goal in the current study was to understand how such offenders’ views and concerns about life, death, and religion interact with extant structural and cultural factors to generate serious criminal behavior, and more specifically, how offender decision-making processes are driven by the dynamic interaction of social, psychological, and cultural variables that comprise the interaction between background and foreground factors of crime (see Katz, 1988; Wright and Topalli, 2011; Wright et al., 2006). Put simply, while quantitative data are well qualified to establish that a relationship between variables like religious belief and criminality exists, qualitative data are useful for contextualizing this relationship; disentangling the unique contributions and interactions of such variables as religious belief, fear, subcultural views and avidity to serious street crime. As such, we elected to investigate these issues employing a qualitative approach, targeted toward active, hardcore street offenders. Our strategy was inspired by the notion that to understand the offender’s perspective it is critical to go beyond simple description and investigate the subjective, lived experiences of those who partake in crime and violence (see Feeney, 1986; Jacques and Wright, 2008, 2010; Schinkel, 2004).

We conducted our interviews with noninstitutionalized individuals rather than taking the more traditional route of interviewing those who were incarcerated. Although an offender’s incarcerated status may be seen as a valid and compelling indicator of deviance (and thus an appropriate starting point for understanding criminality), incarceration itself is problematic when attempting to understand the decision-making processes that lead to crime out on the streets.

To begin, the interview setting is a critical component of the interview process. It maintains the potential to significantly alter or distort the offender’s perceptions, memories, and responses during the interview and must be carefully considered with an eye toward maximizing the external validity of the research endeavor at hand (see Jacques and Wright, 2010; Lee, 1995; Spradley, 1979; Topalli, 2005b; Wright and Decker, 1994, 1997; cf. Copes and Vieraitis, 2008). While interviewing offenders in prison may provide valid and important information on such topics as prison life, rehabilitation, or reentry, it is less well suited to helping us understand how offenders decide to commit crimes when they are free (Jacobs, 2006; Maruna and Copes, 2005; Presser, 2004, 2010). Prisoners are, by definition, out of criminal circulation. In attempting to understand how and why offenders decide to engage in violent crime, it is important to determine if a logical distinction can be made between the information provided by offenders distal to their offending activity (i.e. in prison) versus those who were proximal to the same (i.e. on the outside).

Finally, most prisons employ rehabilitation programs run by faith-based groups, with a good deal of content focused on religious instruction or at least steeped in religious language (see O’Connor et al., 2006; Sumter and Clear, 2005). The implementation of these programs in the rehabilitative setting of prison is problematic when the aim of research is to identify the manner in which religious beliefs affect wrongdoing among those operating in criminogenic situations and settings outside prison (cf. Kerley et al., 2010). While faith-based prison programs deliver a religious-based message of rehabilitation (see Adler et al., 2008), the streets deliver a different message altogether. There, the salient concern for offenders is not rehabilitation or redemption but the principles of violence, retaliation, and self-interest (see Anderson, 1999; Berg and Stewart, 2009; Stewart et al., 2006). Given that our goal was to identify how religion interacts with those principles to encourage or discourage criminality and violence, we logically pursued a data collection strategy aimed at those living and operating in the streets.

sec.title: Setting
sec.p: For a variety of (unfortunate) reasons, Atlanta is well positioned to serve as a setting for studies on urban crime and violence. Atlanta has been identified as a ‘primary distribution center’ for illicit drugs within the state of Georgia, serving as ‘both a final destination point for drug shipments and a smuggling corridor for drugs transported along the East Coast’ (Drug Enforcement Agency, 2008). Moreover, the city suffers a homicide rate that is close to four times the national average and its overall crime rate ranks among the top 10 for major metropolitan areas in the United States (Federal Bureau of Investigation, 2010). We focused our data collection efforts on two parts of the city; Central West Atlanta (CWA) and South Atlanta. According to the Atlanta Police Department’s Crime Analysis Unit, CWA represented only 10 percent (48,216) of the city’s population in 2005–2009; yet it accounted for 20 percent of all city homicides, 22 percent of the rapes, 22 percent of the robberies, and 29 percent of the aggravated assaults known to police. South Atlanta evidenced similarly lop-sided rates based on its population (13 percent of the population with 28 percent of homicides, 18 percent of rapes, 27 percent of robberies, and 31 percent of assaults).

sec.title: Participants and recruitment
sec.p: Our sample of 48 participants was comprised entirely of African Americans, with an average age of 26, and included six females. Our recruiter (an African American male) is a seasoned veteran of Atlanta’s criminal underworld.3 Now in his early 40s, he participated in a variety of criminal activities throughout his teens, 20s, and 30s (including robbery and drug dealing), developing a fearsome and well-respected reputation among community members and offenders alike in South Atlanta and CWA. He was instructed to identify and locate participants for the study who fell within our stated inclusion criteria; offenders actively involved in serious street crime throughout their career with four or more serious offenses (drug dealing, robbery, carjacking, burglary) within the past year.

A common refrain on the streets is that one should ‘never do anything for nothing’ (see Anderson, 1994; Topalli and Wright, 2004). Offenders value their time and are unconcerned with the notion that they should ‘help’ researchers with their work in any context. As such, we paid them a $50 incentive for their participation in the study. Our recruiter was paid a $50 referral fee per successful interview. We maintained the anonymity of participants by never asking for their real names, assuring them that the interviews were to be used solely for the purpose of research, paying them in cash, and referencing them only by their street nick-names in the current work. For those who did not wish to have their street names used, we have substituted fictitious names (only two offenders asked for this). To protect the identities of the interviewees we never recorded their names and retained strict control over interview content (erasing digital recordings after transcription). To limit the possibility that interviewees would be vulnerable to the ill intentions of other offenders, we do not share information about offender activities across interviewees and the recruiter has been instructed to do the same. Finally, though our data have not been subpoenaed by the authorities, we take great care not to ask interviewees about the specific dates, times or locations of their offenses or any other identifying information that could make them vulnerable to prosecution.

sec.title: Procedures and analysis
sec.p: Interviews lasted from 45 to 120 minutes and were conducted between 2009 and 2011. Twenty-nine interviews took place in the authors’ private offices on campus. In such cases, the recruiter drove the participants to our offices escorting them on and off campus. The remainder of our interviews were conducted on the streets of CWA and South Atlanta at fast-food restaurants, public parks, in other outdoor public areas, or in cars; wherever the interviewees and the researchers felt comfortable.

The purpose of conducting interviews on the street was two-fold. First, many offenders balked at the prospect of being interviewed on a university campus, feeling more comfortable in their own surroundings. Second, conducting interviews in their home territory sometimes enhanced the offenders’ recall of key events, providing us with richer detail on important aspects of the interview topic at hand. Engaging offenders on their home turf does carry a certain amount of risk. Lee (1995: 4–5) identifies two kinds of danger that arise from such activities; ambient danger to the interviewer (‘when the researcher is exposed to otherwise avoidable dangers simply by having to be in a dangerous setting’) and situational danger (which ‘arises when the researcher’s presence or actions evoke aggression, hostility, or violence from those within the setting’). As researchers experienced with this kind of work (see, for example, Brezina and Topalli, 2012; Brezina et al., 2009; Topalli, 2005a, 2005b, 2006, etc.) we have become adept at avoiding the latter type of danger—through common sense, maintaining cell phone contact with colleagues when out on the street, not carrying or displaying excessive cash, and observing a discreet profile—and have accepted the former as an unavoidable but necessary cost of engaging in this type of research.4

Interviews were digitally recorded (and later transcribed verbatim, amounting to 778 pages of transcripts). We employed a predetermined question-and-answer protocol designed to extract key concepts and domains (see Spradley, 1979), but the interviews were semi-structured and conducted in an informal, conversational manner. We were particularly keen on allowing participants to respond freely and to introduce their own concepts and categories, thus avoiding the perception on their part that the ‘conversation’ was a formal question-and-answer interview. This approach has been employed successfully in many previous ethnographic studies of active (see, for example, Brezina et al., 2009; Topalli and Wright, 2004; Tyler and Johnson, 2004; Wright and Decker, 1994, 1997) and institutionalized (see, for example, Blatier, 2000; Cherbonneau and Copes, 2006; Copes and Hochstetler, 2003; Shover and Honaker, 1992) offenders. Coding of the interviews was conducted by the authors and two research assistants. Domains and concept categories were compared and contrasted. Repeat coding was employed to more clearly identify core concepts. Data that were determined to be inconsistent across coders were not utilized.

sec.title: Anticipating an early death: ‘cause you don’t know if you gonna live to see next year’
sec.p: Consistent with the results of Brezina et al.’s (2009) work, the offenders we interviewed regularly stated that they anticipated an early death. Forty of the 48 respondents made statements along the following lines: ‘I do [think about dying] … I’ve done woke up in the morning and [thought] I might, I might. Think I might die today or I might not make it’ (LayLow, male, 22, robber).

In many cases, when pressed to explain where such attitudes came from most referenced how dangerous street life was in general and how their day-today activities placed them at risk for violence. As Jersey (male, 37, drug dealer) put it,
Do I think about dying soon? Man you got to think about what you doing here because you’re taking your life not only in your hands but taking your future too …’cause they’ll kill you man. In my neighborhood man, somebody find out you got $2–3000 they will kill you man and leave you on the side of the road. The thing about robbing man is when you rob, you either go out to rob, kill, or be killed. There could be a time when I go to rob somebody’s house and they could be waiting on me to kill me.

It was during these points in our interviews that the offenders’ mortality became more salient. Their discussions and descriptions of violence naturally invoked notions of existential and transcendental outcomes, and we used these opportunities to inquire about their views on religion and spirituality. Consequently, we were able to reference these themes to invoke discussions and consideration of how the offender’s criminal decision-making process was influenced in some fashion by these views. Many interviewees (roughly half) stipulated that their participation in violent crime was inappropriate and believed that their lives could be cut short within the context of divine retribution:
Well, you know, what I think about a lot is, I shoulda’ been dead a long time ago. God has kept me around for a certain reason you know, I worry about it because I can’t say that I’m not afraid to die, you know, ’cause I am. Either I’m gonna die to the streets, die to the drugs, or somebody gonna kill me, you know. One of these. (Detroit, male, 47, carjacker, robber)

One might view such admissions of iniquity on the part of cold-blooded, hard-core offenders as antithetical to offending (and therefore a deterrent to such behavior). However, Sykes and Matza (1957; see also Matza, 1964) demonstrated that while many offenders acknowledge that offending is wrong, they proceed with their transgressions by engaging in self-deceptive cognitive exercises (i.e. neutralizations) to overcome such considerations (see also, Matza, 1964). For our offenders, this process of self-deception was demonstrably complex and, as will be seen below, they employed a variety of such techniques to support their continued offending. This pattern became apparent as we moved the discussion from how imperiled offenders felt to their considerations of God, religion, and the afterlife. A surprising number of offenders proclaimed their belief in a higher power, and that they were adherents to a specific religion (44 of 48 claiming to be Christian, one claiming to be Muslim and three claiming to be atheists):
Yeah, I believe in God. I love God, you know what I mean? I put Him first and foremost [before] anything. Yes indeed I believe in God. I know you looking at me like, how’s that? How’s he believe in God with all the shit he do? But I do man. I know the Bible, I been to church. I pray on shit all the time. I mean, look around. All this [waving his hands up to the sky and to the surrounding area] didn’t just pop outta nothing. If God didn’t make it, who did? You? (LayLow)
Yeah, I was going to church. Baptist Church. But then I converted to Islam. I’m a believer man. I believe in all that, in God. Someday I will go to Mecca for the Hajj. I still try to attend two mosques every chance I get. Give my soul the right state of mind. ’Cause I know you can’t pray in Hell. See, I know Allah knows that this is not the life I wanted. I think that it is the graciousness of Allah that I have been protected. (Smitty, male, 45, drug addict, robber)

These kinds of statements provided us with the opportunity to juxtapose their offending with their purported religiousness. What emerged from these discussions was that offenders were able to use a variety of cognitive self-deceptions to not only reconcile, justify, and excuse their criminality, but to formulate the transcendental consequential constructs of religion as reasons for their offending.

sec.title: Religion as a reason to offend: ‘Its like I’m giving punishment to them for Jesus’
sec.p: The results of our study suggest that counterintuitive understandings or manipulations of religious doctrine facilitate crime in three ways (see below).5 Whether such ‘misuses’ of religious doctrine are willful or genuine, the consequence is that offenders were often able to apply them as a basis for defending their criminality through a variety of a priori neutralizations (see Sykes and Matza, 1957) and a posteriori excuses and justifications (see Scott and Lyman, 1968).

First, offenders’ religious beliefs may be incomplete; many interviewees lacked a clear or comprehensive understanding of the precepts, rules, and expectations of their faith. Thus, offenders’ predictions or beliefs regarding the transcendental consequences of their criminality were simply imprecise, albeit supportive of offending. In fact, we found that while offenders strongly proclaimed their faith, many had only a cursory understanding of the specifics of religious doctrine, including such important concepts as the nature of the afterlife, and the conditions that establish transcendental punishment. Often, offenders were well aware of such knowledge deficits. For example, Gutter, a 24-year-old male robber, stated, ‘I believe but I don’t read the Bible. I don’t go to church. I sit by myself and pray though. I know, shit, I know there is a God up there.’ Que, an 18-year-old male robber, echoed these sentiments:

speech.speaker: Que:
speech.p: I believe in God and the Bible and stuff. I believe in Christmas, and uh, you know the commitments and what not.

speech.speaker: Que:
speech.p: Yeah that. I believe in that.

speech.speaker: Int:
speech.p: Can you name any of them?

speech.speaker: Que:
speech.p: Ahhh … well, I don’t know … like don’t steal, and uh, don’t cheat and shit like that. Uhmm … I can’t remember the rest.

speech.speaker: Que:
speech.p: Yeah I know some of that. You know. Heaven and Hell, and Jesus fighting with the Devil, but for real, I didn’t really go to church enough to know like all the details, just the important shit, like Jesus forgives you for all your bad shit if you donate some money to the church, or pray and say you’re sorry.

sec.p:
Such incomplete understandings often supported criminalistics beliefs. When we pointed out to Triggerman (a 33-year-old enforcer and hit-man for local drug dealers in New Orleans) that the ‘transcendental penalty’ for murder was eternal damnation (a crime he had committed), his response was,
No, no, no, I don’t think that is right. I mean, anything can be forgiven. We live in Hell now and you can do anything [transgression] in Hell. When it all end … we go up there [to Heaven] and the Devil comes down here. Only the Devil lives in Hell forever man all by his self. God has to forgive everyone, even if they don’t believe in him.

Other offenders voiced similar theological twists regarding the manner in which heaven and hell worked. For example, Detroit, a 47-year-old robber and carjacker believed that, ‘there is a Heaven and there is a Hell, but I believe that it is Hell on earth, and we trying to fight to get [there, to Heaven]. Like it’s Hell on earth, we already in Hell, you know?’

Second, their religious beliefs may be selective; some offenders were aware of religious doctrine but seemed to manipulate or selectively attend to certain precepts though not others to accommodate their self-serving desire to offend. In a number of cases, offenders demonstrated a more purposeful selective understanding of the culpability of their behavior. Major, a 19-year-old male carjacker and robber, exemplified this, ‘I believe in God. Yeah I believe, but there ain’t no such thing as the Devil though. I was raised not to think of no Devil.’ In almost classic positivist phrasing, Young Stunna, a 23-year-old male robber interpreted his faith as excusing criminal behavior for those who were disadvantaged but not for those with means:
Well, you do get punished for doing wrong, but not if you don’t have no choice. It’s like this here. See, if I go and rob a motherfucker then I’m still going to Heaven because … uhm … it’s like, Jesus knows I ain’t have no choice, you know? He know I got a decent heart. He know I’m stuck in the hood and just doing what I gotta do to survive. But you now, if you [poking interviewer in the chest] rob somebody, then you might get punished because you going to the Pearly Gates and Jesus going to be like, why you robbing motherfuckers when I gave you a job and a nice life already? What’s up with that?

A similar self-serving interpretation of religious doctrine was evident in commentary from Cool, a 25-year-old male drug dealer:
The way it work is this. You go out and do some bad and then you ask for forgiveness and Jesus have to give it to you, and you know wipe the slate clean. So, I always do a quick little prayer right before and then I’m cool with Jesus. Also another thing is this; if you doing some wrong to another bad person, like if I go rob a dope dealer or a molester or something, then it don’t count against me because it’s like I’m giving punishment to them for Jesus. That’s God’s will. Oh you molested some kids? Well now I’m [God] sending Cool over your house to get your ass.

Such selective understanding of religious doctrine served offenders well in justifying their behavior, particularly when it came to considering the transcendental consequences of offending. Many offenders expressed a great deal of faith in the forgiving nature of God vis-a-vis themselves, and believed that if there was a Hell, it was reserved for others. Our offenders—who most certainly represent some of the most serious and violent criminals on the streets—frequently declared that their actions warranted dispensation from punishment in the afterlife but that such mercy was not due to others. For example, Erica, a 40-year-old transgender (male to female) robber and con artist stated:
Why I think that [I’m going to heaven]? Because, I have a good heart. I do, I have a good heart. And I have a good soul. You know, I mean, some of the things that I do, I mean, I still look out for people, you know what I’m sayin? And that’s one of the biggest things that God looks at, you know, what would you do for your neighbor? [Those that end up in Hell] are the murderers, rapists, child molesters. People with no kind of morals or values about themselves or about other people.

Finally, it would be unfair to assume that all of our offenders had deeply flawed knowledge of religious doctrine. They were all recruited from neighborhoods where religious institutions (i.e. churches) maintain a consistent presence, where many of them had significant exposure to such institutions as children. Consequently, a number of them seemed to know enough about their religion to argue convincingly that their behavior was in fact permissible (if not condoned). Thus, their beliefs may be technically accurate to stated doctrine but paradoxical to the mainstream approved intent of religion. Religious scripture is known for its complex dialectical nature, its tendency for contradictory edicts (e.g. ‘eye for an eye’ vs ‘turn the other cheek’), and its oftentimes-opaque prose. Given that supposedly educated, mainstream society often disagrees as to the use and meaning of religious text, we would argue that the latter point is in fact at least a strong possibility for offenders operating in criminal subcultures (something that should be jointly explored further by religious and criminological scholars).

To wit, offenders frequently applied their knowledge of religion to support their offending with specific recognition of an omnipotent higher power that permitted or even wanted them to continue their offending. In the former scenario, this was most often tied to a belief in a benevolent and forgiving deity. According to Butter, a 31-year-old male robber, ‘If God wasn’t forgiving, I wouldn’t be living … if you’re praying to God he’s probably protecting you and all that kinda stuff.’ In the latter, their continued offending was often viewed as ‘part of God’s plan’. He would stop their offending at His, not the offender’s, discretion. For example,
Before I do anything, I pray, right, and to me, it keeps me out there longer, until it gets to a point where it seems like God says, ‘Well, I can’t let you get along, I can’t let you do this no more.’ See, I do believe that people can change, but that has to come from the most high. When you get that calling, that is it. You know, I have a cliché that I say … I’m getting high to the day I die. I’m doing this to the day I die, unless the most high intercedes, that is. (New York Red, male, 38, robber)

In other instances, offenders were so bold as to actually attempt to ‘game the system’ so to speak. A particularly colorful example—and one of the clearest instances of a priori neutralizing conveyed to us—was provided by Miami, a 40-year-old male robber:
I think [God] is forgiving ’cause you know, what I learned from going to church, you know, sometimes is that like the guys that was on the cross with Jesus, both of ’em did wrong, and that at the last minute one of them ask God to forgive him … and I figured as long as I be able to ask for forgiveness before I die I’m going to Heaven, but if somebody shoot me and I don’t get no chance to pray, you know, I’m going to Hell. So, I came up with this great idea, that hey, I ask God in advance if I don’t get a chance to pray, to forgive me you know for what I’ve done and then I feel like God know in my heart that I don’t like what I’m doing but that’s the only thing I know to do.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: Although conventional wisdom may suggest that adherence to religious doctrine and the commission of predatory crimes are mutually exclusive pursuits, the results of our research indicate that this is not always the case. Unlike most studies in this area, our investigation highlights the co-existence of conventional religious beliefs and criminality. Offenders in our study overwhelmingly professed a belief in God and identified themselves with a particular religion, but also regularly engaged in serious criminality. Even more interesting however, our data further suggest a possible criminogenic role for religious belief among our sample of hardcore street offenders; these offenders actively referenced religious doctrine to justify past offenses and to excuse the continuation of serious criminal conduct. In this context, it is important to note that neutralizations cannot be dismissed as a mere post-hoc rationalization of behavior, with no causal role in the decision-making process. Past research indicates that the use of neutralization techniques (e.g. ‘denial of the victim’) predicts future offending, including violent crime (see Agnew, 1994; Maruna and Copes, 2005).

It should be noted that our results do not indicate that this criminogenic effect accrues from the content of religious doctrine per se. Rather it appears to be the result of either an imperfect or purposely distorted understanding of said doctrine, applied by the offender to their decision-making process. As such, offenders’ exploitation or misunderstanding of religion to foster criminal action resembles most strongly the a priori process of neutralizing (Sykes and Matza, 1957) and the a posteriori process of creating justifications and excuses (Scott and Lyman, 1968). In the present study, offenders’ distorted application of religion is grounded in counteracting the deterrent effect that existential and transcendental consequences of anticipated, current, or previous criminal activity typically have. When successful, these distortions strategically permit or foster participation in criminality.

The co-existence of crime and religious belief, by itself, may not be surprising to those familiar with the thinking patterns of serious criminals. As Walters (1990) observes, ‘discontinuity’ is a hallmark of criminal thinking, in which offenders may say one thing (‘I plan to give up crime’) but do another (engage in robbery). Discontinuity is said to be a product of the lazy and immature thinking style common among offenders, who make little attempt to reconcile blatantly contradictory beliefs and behaviors. Our findings, however, suggest that religious belief and criminality co-exist in a manner that is more complex and consequential than mere discontinuity. The offenders in our sample seemed to go out of their way to reconcile their belief in God with their serious predatory offending. They frequently employed elaborate and creative rationalizations in the process and actively exploit religious doctrine to justify their crimes. Moreover, as stated earlier, there is reason to believe that these rationalizations and justifications may play a criminogenic role in their decision making.

Assuming our interpretation is correct, it is important to consider the policy implications of our findings. A growing correctional reform that pertains to this study is that of faith-based programs, some of which encourage inmates’ participation in prayer, Bible studies, and religious services. There is some evidence that faith-based programs can reduce recidivism, especially when they incorporate educational, vocational, and life-skills training (Dodson et al., 2011; Hercik et al., 2004; Johnson, 2004; LaVigne et al., 2007; O’Connor et al., 1997). However, to the extent that some offenders misinterpret or distort religious teachings to justify and excuse crime, the full potential of faith-based programming may have yet to be realized. Program facilitators may benefit from knowledge of the particular distortions and misunderstandings that some offenders apply to their behavior, and may work to challenge or correct these errors.

Finally, the results of this study may help to explain the inconsistent results that have been produced by past research, with some studies finding an inhibiting effect of religious belief on crime and others finding no effect (see Baier and Wright, 2001). If, as we have argued, religious belief deters crime for most people, but facilitates criminal conduct for certain subgroups, then such mixed results would not be surprising. Offenders operate within a context very different from those in mainstream society. Their willingness and desire to offend is embedded within ongoing lifestyles that must maintain a certain amount of practicality within such contexts. When seemingly conflicting or incongruous social and cultural information associated with the larger culture (such as religious doctrine advocating prosocial behavior) enters into the picture, such information must either be actively ignored or somehow integrated into the offender’s decision-making processes so as to not impede the criminal functionality of said lifestyles. In the present case, we find that offenders have a propensity to co-opt religious doctrine to permit and even encourage their criminal activity, thereby preserving their identity as criminals and maintaining their ability to pursue illicit action.

Phillip Zimbardo and colleagues have advanced this notion through the development of a Time Perspective Inventory that measures, among other things, the effect that transcendental future expectations (i.e. notions or beliefs that individuals hold regarding the afterlife) may have on present behavior. According to Zimbardo and Boyd (2008: 172–173), ‘The transcendental–future time perspective extends from the death of the physical body to eternity’ (see also Boyd and Zimbardo, 1997). When people consider only their present circumstances and ‘traditional’ or ‘mundane’ future (i.e. that time proceeding from the present up until death) the impact of those considerations on the motivational mechanisms that underpin behaviors (both positive and negative) weakens with the passage of time. However, since the afterlife – as it is perceived by most in conventional western culture – is eternal and not empirically disprovable (i.e. based on belief and faith), its capacity to motivate behavior is essentially limitless. Therefore, behaviors energized by such beliefs are thought to be highly resistant to change (Boyd and Zimbardo, 1997).

For example, robbers who specialize in victimizing drug dealers employ an array of retaliatory threat management techniques before committing such offenses to avoid subsequent potential injury or death and ensure that they will be able to continue offending in the future (see Jacobs et al., 2000; Topalli et al., 2002).

It should be noted that both South Atlanta and CWA are overwhelmingly African American (96 percent in some neighborhoods). Since our recruiter engaged with other offenders within his own network of acquaintances, and was more likely to have had interactions with offenders of his own race, our sample was entirely African American.
For any excellent discussion of the risks of this kind of work see Bourgois and Schonberg’s book, Righteous Dopefiend (2009).

We wish to thank the anonymous reviewers for convincing us to reconceptualize this section. In identifying the different ways that offenders reconcile their religious beliefs with their offending our approach is reminiscent of Kenneth Pargament’s (1997) work on how people use religion to cope with life’s stress. Pargament identifies three styles of coping with life’s stressors: those who apply the deferring style delegate problem solving to God (it is in His hands); those who apply the self-directing style reference the power of God to solve problems on their own (He gives me strength to do what needs to be done); and those who apply a collaborative style treat God as their collaborator, a facilitator of the problem-solving process (He is on my side as I move forward with my solution).

bio.p: Volkan Topalli is Associate Professor of Criminal Justice &Criminology at Georgia State University (GSU). His research and teaching interests include street violence, drug markets, and active offender decision making. Recent publications have appeared in the journals Criminology, Justice Quarterly, Criminal Justice & Behavior, and the British Journal of Criminology.

Timothy Brezina is Associate Professor of Criminal Justice and Criminology at Georgia State University. His research interests include criminological theory, youth violence, and punishment and deterrence. Recent publications appear in the journals Criminology, Criminal Justice and Behavior, and Deviant Behavior. He is also co-author of Juvenile Delinquency: Causes and Control, 4th edition (with Robert Agnew, Oxford University Press).

Mindy Bernhardt is a PhD candidate in criminal justice and criminology at Georgia State University. Her research interests include decision making of hardcore offenders, street culture, and theory testing and development.
